text: I have to disagree. You can call it trading and yes you may be profitable but placing a bet is always gambling. I will get shot down for the opinion but if you are placing bets you are gambling - they are not guaranteed to win. It bugs me when people try and sanitise what we do - call it what it is. Being automated does not change what we fundamentally are doing here.

text: <@ULDAVFDRP> The link in terminology I understand and I have even seen people use the logic that using an exchange is a "trade" of opinions but I see it simply as placing a bet where the party accepting the risk is not necessarily a bookie. A lot of people (particularly on social media) like to distance themselves from the term "gambling" and not always because they are trying to sell tips or some useless ebook on how to "trade betfair". I understand there are times when you may want or need to distance yourself from the term (for example, I recently asked some questions about mortgage providers and gambling transactions) but I am instantly distrusful of people who try and label what we do as anything other than what it actually is. It is not really OUR problem (well, SHOULD not be our problem) that a lot of people in society (usually those who have never set foot in a bookmaker) seem to regard this game as murky or undesirable.

elements.text: The link in terminology I understand and I have even seen people use the logic that using an exchange is a "trade" of opinions but I see it simply as placing a bet where the party accepting the risk is not necessarily a bookie. text:
One of the key differences between stock and gambling,
Gambling is a time-bound event. Stock can be time-rewarding event,
In long term the stock market (US) trends is going up, there is more channce to make a profit.
In long term gambing trends is either flat or down, there is more channce to loss money.
Of course, skill people can still make money either way.

text:
surprised people would call betting with an edge gambling...by that logic surely a Casino or Bookmaker are gambling? But I'd imagine few see it that way.

On here there are a mix of people that know they have an edge and those that aren't yet sure (or simply don't), I would classify those with a known edge differently to those who don't have an edge. The latter being gamblers (even if only temporarily, i.e. they may develop an edge in time)...although no idea admittedly what the correct term for the former group is...bettors maybe?

elements.text:

text: I don't gamble. I am building a business by assessing risk the same way other businesses assess risk. My investment is the time it takes to build the system. text: I can't agree with that <@U016535QCJ2> . For a start, there is more chance you cannot exit a position in a sports market. Also much more chance of losing your position entirely. For example you are a tennis man - what happens to your position if you are on a player who is injured during the match? At least with the stock markets you are always likely to be able to exit - on betfair not so (internet loss, API outage, above example etc)

text: I don't think you can necessarily equate the sophistication of techniques used to determine and place the bets with the action of PLACING a bet. At the end of the day, I can call myself a developer, a mathematician and a data scientist (whatever that term actually means) but no matter how I have wrapped all that up into an application that does the hard work while I perform the day job, it is still just placing bets. It might be doing it with the most sophisticated methods known to man (it isn't but thats another matter) but the outcome is the same - risking my money on the outcome of the sporting event. Gambling if you will

text: <@U016535QCJ2> I don't really understand the question - my job description is "data scientist" if that is what you are asking. In terms of sophistication, I speak with a chap who makes shitloads of money on football basically by getting team/match status news way ahead of other people. There is no "sophistication" in that approach so to speak but he makes lots of profit. What I have is way more computer/algorithm based but I would swap my bank balance with him if offered the chance. He is a professional gambler - would you say that was a fair desrciption? I am sorry but I just cannot see how someone who uses algorithms/analysis should be viewed any differently to someone who reads the racing post and places their bets manually over the counter at the bookies.

text:
You are of course welcome to answer that question however you want

But you said that you have never gambled which is utterly false (unless I have misunderstood your own venture and you personally do not place any bets)

You might have your own incorrect definition of what gambling means but standardised definitions exist for very good reasons, such to facilitate the exchange of ideas. This is not about agreeing to disagree

text: Are UK residents, who call themselves sports traders, setting themselves up for a big tax bill?

elements.text: Are UK residents, who call themselves sports traders, setting themselves up for a big tax bill?

text: Surely if you are placing any bets online in the UK then there would always be an account trace. I am guessing though this would only be via Betfair as a bookie will close you down before you make any serious money. A full bet history would easily keep the tax man away if UK law states that gambling related income is non-taxable?

text: Singing my song. I've been going on about this for years. I think it's dangerous and misleading to new players to call a spade anything but a spade.

elements.text: Singing my song. I've been going on about this for years. I think it's dangerous and misleading to new players to call a spade anything but a spade.

text: Would be interesting to see what happens with decentralised platforms like Augur though in future. Will they tax you for the crypto side of it as well as make you jump through hoops to prove that those transactions were bets.

elements.text: Would be interesting to see what happens with decentralised platforms like Augur though in future. Will they tax you for the crypto side of it as well as make you jump through hoops to prove that those transactions were bets.

text: I think he was playing in person (poker) for cash

text: There will be exceptions but on the whole winners tend to quite comfortable with the term 'gambling'. They don't need to justify their choices because the money does that. The various euphemisms are usually more popular with losers as they support denial.

elements.text: There will be exceptions but on the whole winners tend to quite comfortable with the term 'gambling'. They don't need to justify their choices because the money does that. The various euphemisms are usually more popular with losers as they support denial.

text: Just to be clear I haven't read through all the discussion above, that wasn't directed at any individual and like I said 'there will be exceptions'. Just my observation after having met more than my share of winning and losing gamblers.

text: What I’m wondering is, what if you made your profit with Arbs? So you place bets with theoretically 100% certainty. Is your money still coming from gambling? But you’re not actually gambling. or?

text: You are actually gambling

text: How on earth has this gone on so long? It's not risk or profit that defines gambling. It's placing bets. That's all there is to it.

elements.text: How on earth has this gone on so long? It's not risk or profit that defines gambling. It's placing bets. That's all there is to it.

text: In any case, thanks to this thread I was able to correct wrong assumptions. It is actually a topic that concerns a lot of people.

elements.text: In any case, thanks to this thread I was able to correct wrong assumptions. It is actually a topic that concerns a lot of people.

text: Yes if the upcoming UK government gambling review decides to pull some draconian limits on what people can gamble each month it will concern a lot of people on here I would think. But hopefully nothing too savage will happen.

text: Phew! Now that the consensus of those that replied say that it is gambling, do you think its possible to get addicted to automated gambling? As someone who has traded almost everyday for 14 years and form all parts of the globe, Ive often asked myself this. Im lucky in that Im in profit and ive always said that Id drop it like a stone if I ever found it not so. Ive always thought it an intellectual challenge in the same way that someone might immerse themselves in chess for example, but food for thought nonetheless

elements.text: Phew! Now that the consensus of those that replied say that it is gambling, do you think its possible to get addicted to automated gambling? As someone who has traded almost everyday for 14 years and form all parts of the globe, Ive often asked myself this. Im lucky in that Im in profit and ive always said that Id drop it like a stone if I ever found it not so. Ive always thought it an intellectual challenge in the same way that someone might immerse themselves in chess for example, but food for thought nonetheless

text: Not sure, AFAIK (hence take it with a grain of salt) addiction is very tied to psychological predisposition, rather than to the thing you get addicted to (unless it's physical, i.e. drugs)

elements.text: Not sure, AFAIK (hence take it with a grain of salt) addiction is very tied to psychological predisposition, rather than to the thing you get addicted to (unless it's physical, i.e. drugs)

text: I think you can get obsessed with it in the sense that you spend more dev time than you should at times (just my experience) but that depends on your entry into the game. And you have to put the work into it if you want to get anywhere. But not sure you can get "addicted" to it if its an algorithmic approach? I'm certainly guilty of spending more time than I should developing stuff though. But that applies to programmers from all disciplines I imagine.

elements.text: I think you can get obsessed with it in the sense that you spend more dev time than you should at times (just my experience) but that depends on your entry into the game. And you have to put the work into it if you want to get anywhere. But not sure you can get "addicted" to it if its an algorithmic approach? I'm certainly guilty of spending more time than I should developing stuff though. But that applies to programmers from all disciplines I imagine.

text: What I'd be rather afraid of is that if it goes awry after a while what do you do with your skills.. :face_with_monocle:

elements.text: What I'd be rather afraid of is that if it goes awry after a while what do you do with your skills..

text: <@UQL0QDEKA> - Yes - I think this can be a real problem. Part of my distaste for the euphemisms is that they enable people to pretend that they're not problem gamblers. Gambling is dangerous and can ruin your life. I think it's important that we keep sight of that and don't sugar coat it.

elements.text: - Yes - I think this can be a real problem. Part of my distaste for the euphemisms is that they enable people to pretend that they're not problem gamblers. Gambling is dangerous and can ruin your life. I think it's important that we keep sight of that and don't sugar coat it.

text: We have a very significant issue with problem gamblers in Australia. But that's across slot machines (the worst), sports betting, and to a lesser extent, casinos. Of those with problems, less than 0.01% (if that) would be people who do some sort of computer analysis and then use that to bet. We just aren't the problem group. Those pretending they are not problem gamblers aren't using euphemisms, they are denying an addiction

elements.text: We have a very significant issue with problem gamblers in Australia. But that's across slot machines (the worst), sports betting, and to a lesser extent, casinos. Of those with problems, less than 0.01% (if that) would be people who do some sort of computer analysis and then use that to bet. We just aren't the problem group. Those pretending they are not problem gamblers aren't using euphemisms, they are denying an addiction

text: And unfortunately it seems to be facilitated by club/pub owners (slot machines) and betting agencies, who treat losers like VIPs and extend all sorts of privileges to them
